header_summary:
The first email introduces the concept of "PathCoin" and its potential for transferring coins. It discusses the use of "Cold channels" and "CTLCs" to control the flow of money, providing an example of how chaining participants works. Optimistic PathCoin and its limitations are also mentioned, along with the idea of using multiple channels simultaneously to improve routing.

In the second email, Antoine addresses safety issues faced by lightning and other second-layer protocols when blocks are full. He suggests different options to address these issues, including reverting to a static world with no replacement-by-fee mechanism or implementing policies to capture transaction-issuer intent. Antoine also mentions the possibility of allowing a fragmented mempool environment or making consensus changes to align incentives.

The third email announces the availability of Bitcoin Core version v26.0rc2 for download. The previous release candidate had packaging issues with macOS binaries, but they have been resolved in the current release candidate. Once thoroughly tested without critical problems, it will be tagged as the official release of Bitcoin Core v26.0, indicating its stability and readiness for public use.

recent_posts.title: The Pinning & Replacement Problem Set
recent_posts.summary:

- Antoine suggests options to address the issue, including reverting to a static world or implementing policies.

active_posts.title: Full Disclosure: CVE-2023-40231 / CVE-2023-40232 / CVE-2023-40233 / CVE-2023-40234 "All your mempool are belong to us"
active_posts.summary:
- A new transaction-relay jamming attack called replacement cycling was discovered in December 2022.
- Mitigations have been implemented in major lightning implementations to address this attack.
- Other bitcoin applications using bitcoin script timelocks or multi-party transactions may also be affected.

active_posts.title: [Mempool spam] Should we as developers reject non-standard Taproot transactions from full nodes?
active_posts.summary:
- The Bitcoin network faces congestion due to side projects like BRC-20, affecting transactions.
- Possible solutions include implementing BIPs or pruning non-standard Taproot transactions.
- Critics argue against limiting freedom, but congestion prevention measures are necessary.

active_posts.title: OP_Expire and Coinbase-Like Behavior: Making HTLCs Safer by Letting Transactions Expire Safely
active_posts.summary:
- The email addresses the issue of the spendability of the HTLC-preimage path even after the HTLC-timeout path is available.
- The proposal suggests using OP_Expire and the Coinbase Bit soft-fork upgrade to solve the problem.
- OP_Expire can be added to the pre-image branch of the script to create a deadline for the receiving party in HTLCs.
